title: Rectangular Beam Flexural Design
problem: Design a rectangular reinforced concrete beam to span 22 feet and support a service dead load of 1.2 kip/ft (including self-weight) and a service live load of 1.8 kip/ft. Use f'c = 5,000 psi and Grade 60 reinforcement. The beam width is limited to 14 inches. Determine the required beam depth and reinforcement. Use φ = 0.90 for tension-controlled sections.
given: Service dead load wD = 1.2 kip/ft (includes self-weight)
required: Determine the required beam depth (h) and tension reinforcement area (As).

solution_steps.title: Determine Depth for Tension-Controlled Section
solution_steps.content: For tension-controlled behavior: εt ≥ 0.005, which corresponds to c/d ≤ 0.375. The balanced condition: cb/d = 0.003/(0.003 + 0.005) = 0.375. For f'c = 5000 psi and fy = 60000 psi: ρb = 0.85β1(f'c/fy)(87/(87+fy)) where β1 = 0.85 - 0.05(5000-4000)/1000 = 0.80. ρb = 0.85(0.80)(5/60)(87/147) = 0.0285. For tension-controlled: ρmax = 0.375ρb = 0.0107

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Steel Area
solution_steps.content: Using the equation: Mu = φAsfy(d - a/2) where a = Asfy/(0.85f'cb). Rearranging: Asfy(d - Asfy/(1.7f'cb)) = Mu/φ. Let As = unknown: As×60×(21.5 - As×60/(1.7×5×14)) = 3136.8/0.9. 60As(21.5 - 0.504As) = 3485.3. This is a quadratic: 30.24As² - 1290As + 3485.3 = 0. Solving: As = 2.89 in²

solution_steps.title: Select Bars
solution_steps.content: Use 3-#9 bars: As = 3.00 in² > 2.89 in² ✓. Check bar fit in 14" width: 3 bars at 2.5" spacing minimum = 7.5" + 2(cover) + 2(stirrup) = 7.5 + 3 + 1 = 11.5" < 14" ✓

final_answer: Use a 14 in × 24 in beam with 3-#9 bars (As = 3.00 in²). The effective depth d = 21.5 in provides a tension-controlled section with φ = 0.90. Check shear and deflection for complete design.

title: Beam Shear Design with Stirrups
problem: A 20-inch wide by 28-inch deep (total depth) reinforced concrete beam spans 18 feet and supports a factored uniform load wu = 8.5 kips/ft. Use f'c = 4,000 psi and Grade 60 stirrups. The beam has #4 stirrups with 1.5-inch clear cover. Determine the required stirrup spacing at the critical section located at distance d from the support.
given: Beam dimensions: b = 20 in, h = 28 in
required: Determine the required stirrup spacing at the critical section (d from support).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Shear at Critical Section
solution_steps.content: Support reaction: Vu_support = wuL/2 = 8.5(18)/2 = 76.5 kips. Critical section is at distance d from support face. Assuming 12" support width, distance from support center to critical section = 6" + 25.5" = 31.5" = 2.625 ft. Shear at critical section: Vu = 76.5 - 8.5(2.625/2) = 76.5 - 11.2 = 65.3 kips (approximately). More precisely: Vu = wu(L/2 - d/L) = 8.5(9 - 25.5/12) = 8.5(9 - 2.125) = 58.4 kips. Actually: Vu = 76.5 - 8.5×(25.5/12) = 76.5 - 18.1 = 58.4 kips

solution_steps.title: Calculate Concrete Shear Capacity
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Section 22.5.5.1: Vc = 2√f'c × bd. Vc = 2√4000 × 20 × 25.5 / 1000 = 2(63.2)(510)/1000 = 64.5 kips. Alternatively, using more detailed method: Vc = (1.9λ√f'c + 2500ρwVu/Mu)bd, but simplified method is conservative.

solution_steps.title: Check If Stirrups Are Required
solution_steps.content: φVc = 0.75 × 64.5 = 48.4 kips. Since Vu = 58.4 kips > φVc = 48.4 kips, stirrups are required. Also check: Vu ≤ φ(Vc + Vs). Maximum Vs = 8√f'c × bd = 8(63.2)(510)/1000 = 258 kips.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Stirrup Spacing
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Section 22.5.10.5.3: Vs = Avfyd/s. Solving for s: s = Avfyd/Vs = 0.40(60,000)(25.5)/(13,400) = 612,000/13,400 = 45.7 in. Maximum spacing limits: s_max = min(d/2, 24 in) = min(12.75 in, 24 in) = 12.75 in. Also, minimum shear reinforcement: s_max = Avfy/(0.75√f'c × b) = 0.40(60,000)/(0.75×63.2×20) = 25.2 in. Or s_max = Avfy/(50b) = 0.40(60,000)/(50×20) = 24 in. The smaller of s_max and calculated spacing governs: s = 12.75 in. Use s = 12 in for convenience.

final_answer: Use #4 stirrups at 12 inches on center near the supports. This provides φ(Vc + Vs) = 86.6 kips > Vu = 58.4 kips. The spacing can be increased farther from the supports as Vu decreases. Check maximum spacing requirements throughout the beam length.

title: Slender Column Design
problem: Design a tied rectangular column for the following loads: Pu = 850 kips (factored axial load) and Mu = 120 kip-ft (factored moment about strong axis). The column is part of a braced frame with an unsupported length of Lu = 16 ft. Use f'c = 6,000 psi and Grade 60 reinforcement. The column dimensions are 18 in × 18 in. Check if slenderness effects must be considered and design the reinforcement.
required: Check slenderness effects and determine required reinforcement.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Slenderness Ratio
solution_steps.content: For a rectangular column: r = 0.30h = 0.30(18) = 5.4 in. For braced frame, effective length factor K is typically between 0.7 and 1.0. Assume K = 0.9 (can be refined with alignment charts). Slenderness ratio: λ = KL/r = 0.9(16×12)/5.4 = 32. Also calculate for weak axis with same dimensions.

solution_steps.title: Check If Slenderness Must Be Considered
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Section 6.2.5, for braced (non-sway) frames: λ < 34 - 12(M1/M2) is the threshold for neglecting slenderness. For single curvature (M1/M2 = 1), threshold = 34 - 12(1) = 22. For double curvature (M1/M2 = -1), threshold = 34 - 12(-1) = 46. Since λ = 32, slenderness effects must be considered unless M1/M2 ≤ -0.33. Moment magnification method will be used.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Moment Magnification Factor
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Section 6.6.4: δs = Cm / (1 - Pu/φPc) ≥ 1.0. For columns in braced frames: δ = Cm / (1 - Pu/(0.75Pc)) ≥ 1.0. Cm = 0.6 + 0.4(M1/M2). Assuming single curvature (Cm = 1.0 for uniform moment). Calculate critical buckling load Pc: EI = (0.2EcIg + EsIse) or EI = 0.25EcIg/(1 + βds). Ec = 57,000√f'c = 57,000√6000 = 4,415,000 psi. Ig = bh³/12 = 18³/12 = 4,860 in⁴. EI = 0.25(4,415)(4,860) = 5,363,000 kip-in². Pc = π²EI/(KL)² = π²(5,363,000)/(0.9×192)² = 52,930,000/29,850 = 1,773 kips. δ = 1.0 / (1 - 850/(0.75×1,773)) = 1.0 / (1 - 0.639) = 2.78. This is excessive (>1.4), indicating potential instability.

solution_steps.title: Recalculate with Different Assumptions
solution_steps.content: The high magnification factor suggests the column is near its buckling capacity. Consider: (1) Larger column section, (2) Double curvature loading, or (3) Reduced effective length. For double curvature: Cm = 0.6 + 0.4(-1) = 0.2. δ = 0.2/(1-0.639) = 0.55 < 1.0, use δ = 1.0. This means if the column is in double curvature (moment reverses), slenderness effects can be neglected.

solution_steps.title: Design for Combined Loading
solution_steps.content: Assuming δ = 1.0 (double curvature or stiff framing), design for Pu = 850 kips and Mu = 120 kip-ft. Use interaction diagram from ACI SP-17 or calculate. e = Mu/Pu = 120×12/850 = 1.69 in. e/h = 1.69/18 = 0.094. For small eccentricity, column is compression-controlled. Gross area Ag = 18² = 324 in². Required nominal strength: Pn = Pu/φ = 850/0.65 = 1308 kips (assuming compression-controlled, φ = 0.65). Pn,max = 0.80[0.85fc(Ag - Ast) + fyAst]. Let Ast = unknown: 1308 = 0.80[0.85(6)(324 - Ast) + 60Ast]. 1308/0.80 = 1635 = 5.1(324 - Ast) + 60Ast. 1635 = 1652 - 5.1Ast + 60Ast. 1635 = 1652 + 54.9Ast. Ast = (1635 - 1652)/54.9 = -0.31 in². This indicates Ast < 0, so minimum steel controls.

solution_steps.title: Apply Minimum Reinforcement
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Section 10.6.1.1: Ast,min = 0.01Ag = 0.01(324) = 3.24 in². Ast,max = 0.08Ag = 25.9 in². Use Ast = 3.24 in² minimum. Select 8-#6 bars: As = 8(0.44) = 3.52 in² > 3.24 in² ✓. Check spacing and bar fit.

final_answer: Use 18 in × 18 in column with 8-#6 bars (Ast = 3.52 in²). The slenderness ratio λ = 32 requires moment magnification. If the column is in single curvature, the design should be reconsidered with a larger section. For double curvature (common in braced frames with beam continuity), the design is adequate with φPn ≈ 1000 kips.

title: One-Way Slab Design
problem: Design a one-way slab spanning 10 feet between supports. The slab supports a superimposed dead load of 25 psf and a live load of 100 psf. Use f'c = 4,000 psi and Grade 60 reinforcement. Determine the slab thickness and required reinforcement for a 1-foot wide strip.
required: Determine slab thickness (h) and required reinforcement area per foot width.

solution_steps.title: Determine Minimum Slab Thickness
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Table 7.3.1.1 for one-way slabs (solid slabs): For one-end continuous: h_min = L/24 = 10×12/24 = 5.0 in. For both-ends continuous: h_min = L/28 = 4.29 in. Minimum thickness for practical construction: 5 inches (to accommodate reinforcement with adequate cover).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Loads Per Foot Width
solution_steps.content: Slab self-weight = h × 150 pcf = 5/12 × 150 = 62.5 psf. Total dead load = 62.5 + 25 = 87.5 psf = 0.0875 ksf. Live load = 100 psf = 0.100 ksf. Factored load: wu = 1.2D + 1.6L = 1.2(0.0875) + 1.6(0.100) = 0.105 + 0.160 = 0.265 klf per foot width.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Factored Moments
solution_steps.content: Using approximate moments for continuous slabs (ACI 6.5.2): At interior support: Mu- = wuL²/11 = 0.265(10)²/11 = 2.41 kip-ft per ft. At midspan: Mu+ = wuL²/16 = 0.265(10)²/16 = 1.66 kip-ft per ft. At exterior support: Mu- = wuL²/24 = 0.265(10)²/24 = 1.10 kip-ft per ft. Design for the maximum moment: Mu = 2.41 kip-ft = 28.9 kip-in.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Reinforcement
solution_steps.content: Effective depth d = h - cover - bar/2 = 5 - 0.75 - 0.25 = 4.0 in (assuming #4 bars with 3/4" cover). Using: As = Mu/(φfy(d - a/2)) and a = Asfy/(0.85f'cb). With b = 12 in, trial calculation: Assume a is small, then As ≈ Mu/(φfy×0.9d) = 28.9/(0.9×60×0.9×4.0) = 28.9/194.4 = 0.149 in²/ft. Verify: a = 0.149×60/(0.85×4×12) = 0.22 in. d - a/2 = 4.0 - 0.11 = 3.89 in. Recalculate: As = 28.9/(0.9×60×3.89) = 0.138 in²/ft.

solution_steps.title: Check Minimum Reinforcement
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Section 8.6.1.1: As,min = max(0.0018Ag, 0.002Ag for Grade 60). For temperature and shrinkage: As,min = 0.0018 × 5 × 12 = 0.108 in²/ft. For flexural minimum: As,min = 3√f'c/fy × bd = 3√4000/60000 × 12 × 4.0 = 0.152 in²/ft > 0.138 in². Or As,min = 200/fy × bd = 200/60000 × 48 = 0.160 in²/ft. Minimum controls: As = 0.160 in²/ft.

solution_steps.title: Select Reinforcement
solution_steps.content: Use #4 bars at 15 inches on center: As = 0.20 × 12/15 = 0.16 in²/ft ✓. Maximum spacing: s_max = min(3h, 18 in) = min(15 in, 18 in) = 15 in. For negative moment regions (over supports), add #4 bars at 15 in or place half of bottom bars continuous. Temperature and shrinkage reinforcement: As = 0.0018 × 5 × 12 = 0.108 in²/ft. Use #3 bars at 16 in: As = 0.11 × 12/16 = 0.083 in²/ft < required. Use #3 at 12 in: As = 0.11 in²/ft ✓.

final_answer: Use a 5-inch thick slab with #4 bars at 15 inches on center (bottom, positive moment) providing As = 0.16 in²/ft. Temperature reinforcement: #3 bars at 12 inches on center (top). At supports, add negative moment reinforcement of #4 at 15 inches or make 50% of bottom bars continuous.

title: Reinforced Concrete Beam Shear Design
problem: A simply supported rectangular reinforced concrete beam spans 24 ft and carries a uniform factored load of 4.5 kip/ft (including self-weight). The beam width is 14 in, and the effective depth is 24 in. The concrete compressive strength $f_c' = 4,000$ psi, and the steel yield strength $f_{yt} = 60,000$ psi. Determine the required spacing of #4 stirrups at the critical section for shear. Assume normal-weight concrete. Use ACI 318-14 provisions.
given: Stirrups: #4 bars ($A_v = 2 \times 0.20 = 0.40$ in² for two legs)
required: Determine the required spacing of #4 stirrups at the critical section for shear.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Factored Shear Force at Critical Section
solution_steps.content:
For a simply supported beam with uniform load, the maximum shear occurs at the face of the support. The critical section for shear design is at a distance $d$ from the face of the support (ACI 318-14 Section 22.5.4.1).

Assume support width is negligible for this calculation.

Maximum shear at support:
$$V_{u,max} = \frac{w_u L}{2} = \frac{4.5 \times 24}{2} = 54 \text{ kips}$$

Shear at distance $d = 2$ ft from support:
$$V_u = V_{u,max} - w_u \times d$$
$$V_u = 54 - 4.5 \times 2 = 54 - 9 = 45 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Concrete Shear Strength $\phi V_c$
solution_steps.content:
For normal-weight concrete, ACI 318-14 Section 22.5.5.1:
$$V_c = 2 \lambda \sqrt{f_c'} b_w d$$

Where $\lambda = 1.0$ for normal-weight concrete.

$$V_c = 2 \times 1.0 \times \sqrt{4,000} \times 14 \times 24$$
$$\sqrt{4,000} = 63.25 \text{ psi}$$
$$V_c = 2 \times 63.25 \times 14 \times 24$$
$$V_c = 2 \times 63.25 \times 336 = 2 \times 21,252 = 42,504 \text{ lbs} = 42.5 \text{ kips}$$

Strength reduction factor $\phi = 0.75$ for shear (Section 21.2.1).

$$\phi V_c = 0.75 \times 42.5 = 31.9 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Check if Shear Reinforcement is Required
solution_steps.content:
ACI 318-14 Section 9.6.3.1: Minimum shear reinforcement is required if $V_u > 0.5 \phi V_c$.

$$0.5 \phi V_c = 0.5 \times 31.9 = 15.95 \text{ kips}$$

$V_u = 45$ kips $> 15.95$ kips, so shear reinforcement is required.

solution_steps.title: Determine Required Shear Strength from Stirrups
solution_steps.content:
The required shear strength to be provided by stirrups:
$$\phi V_s \ge V_u - \phi V_c$$
$$V_s \ge \frac{V_u - \phi V_c}{\phi}$$

$$V_s \ge \frac{45 - 31.9}{0.75} = \frac{13.1}{0.75} = 17.47 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Stirrup Spacing
solution_steps.content:
For stirrups perpendicular to longitudinal reinforcement (Section 22.5.10.5.3):
$$V_s = \frac{A_v f_{yt} d}{s}$$

Rearranging:
$$s = \frac{A_v f_{yt} d}{V_s}$$

For #4 stirrups with two legs: $A_v = 0.40$ in².
$$s = \frac{0.40 \times 60 \times 24}{17.47}$$
$$s = \frac{576}{17.47} = 32.97 \text{ in}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Maximum Spacing Limitations
solution_steps.content:
From ACI 318-14 Section 9.7.6.2.2, maximum stirrup spacing is the smaller of:

Check if $V_s \le 4 \sqrt{f_c'} b_w d$:
$$4 \sqrt{f_c'} b_w d = 4 \times 63.25 \times 14 \times 24 = 4 \times 21,252 = 85,008 \text{ lbs} = 85.0 \text{ kips}$$
$V_s = 17.47$ kips $< 85.0$ kips, so:
$$s_{max} = \min\left(\frac{d}{2}, 24\text{ in}\right)$$
$$s_{max} = \min(12, 24) = 12 \text{ in}$$

Also check minimum shear reinforcement from Section 9.6.3.3:
$$A_{v,min} = 0.75 \sqrt{f_c'} \frac{b_w s}{f_{yt}} \ge \frac{50 b_w s}{f_{yt}}$$
For $s = 12$ in:
$0.75\sqrt{4000} \times 14 \times 12 / 60,000 = 0.75 \times 63.25 \times 168 / 60,000 = 7,969 / 60,000 = 0.133$ in².
$50 \times 14 \times 12 / 60,000 = 8,400 / 60,000 = 0.14$ in².
$A_v = 0.40$ in² $> 0.14$ in², OK.

Therefore, maximum spacing controls: $s \le 12$ in.

Use $s = 12$ in.

final_answer: The required spacing of #4 stirrups at the critical section is $12$ inches.

title: Combined Footing Design for Column Loads
problem: A combined footing supports two 16-in square columns spaced 15 ft apart center-to-center. Column A (exterior) carries a dead load of 120 kips and a live load of 100 kips. Column B (interior) carries a dead load of 200 kips and a live load of 160 kips. The allowable soil bearing pressure is 4,000 psf. The footing is to be rectangular with the length parallel to the column line. Determine the required dimensions (length and width) of the footing such that the resultant of column loads coincides with the centroid of the footing (uniform pressure assumption). Use ASD for soil bearing check. The footing extends 2 ft beyond Column A (exterior face). Neglect footing weight initially, then add for final check.
given: Column A: 16 in square, $P_{D,A} = 120$ kips, $P_{L,A} = 100$ kips
Column B: 16 in square, $P_{D,B} = 200$ kips, $P_{L,B} = 160$ kips
Footing extends 2 ft beyond Column A (exterior face)
required: Determine the required footing length $L$ and width $B$ (ft).
Check if the calculated dimensions satisfy the allowable bearing pressure including footing weight (assume footing thickness = 2.5 ft, concrete unit weight = 150 pcf).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Service Loads (ASD)
solution_steps.content:
Column A: $P_A = P_{D,A} + P_{L,A} = 120 + 100 = 220$ kips
Column B: $P_B = P_{D,B} + P_{L,B} = 200 + 160 = 360$ kips

Total load: $P_{total} = 220 + 360 = 580$ kips

solution_steps.title: Determine Location of Resultant Force
solution_steps.content:
Take moments about Column A centerline.
Column A moment arm = 0 ft
Column B moment arm = 15 ft

Moment about Column A:
$$M_A = P_B \times 15 = 360 \times 15 = 5,400 \text{ ft-kips}$$

Distance of resultant from Column A:
$$x_R = \frac{M_A}{P_{total}} = \frac{5,400}{580} = 9.31 \text{ ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Footing Length for Centroid Alignment
solution_steps.content:
For uniform pressure, the footing centroid must align with the resultant force location.

Given: Footing extends 2 ft beyond Column A (exterior face).
Distance from Column A face to Column A center = 8 in = 0.67 ft.
So, distance from footing edge (beyond Column A) to Column A center = $2 + 0.67 = 2.67$ ft.

Let $L$ = total footing length.
The centroid of the footing is at $L/2$ from the left edge.
For centroid to coincide with resultant at $x_R = 9.31$ ft from Column A center:
Distance from left edge to Column A center = 2.67 ft
Distance from left edge to resultant = $2.67 + 9.31 = 11.98$ ft

Set centroid at this location:
$$\frac{L}{2} = 11.98 \text{ ft}$$
$$L = 23.96 \text{ ft} \approx 24.0 \text{ ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Column Positions within Footing Length
solution_steps.content:
Left edge to Column A center = 2.67 ft
Column A center to Column B center = 15 ft
Column B center to right edge = $L - (2.67 + 15) = 24 - 17.67 = 6.33$ ft

Column B is 16 in square, so distance from Column B center to its face = 0.67 ft.
Distance from Column B face to right edge = $6.33 - 0.67 = 5.66$ ft, which is adequate for development and shear.

solution_steps.title: Determine Required Footing Width for Bearing
solution_steps.content:
Required area based on total load:
$$A_{req} = \frac{P_{total}}{q_{all}} = \frac{580 \text{ kips}}{4.0 \text{ ksf}} = 145 \text{ ft}^2$$

With $L = 24$ ft, required width:
$$B = \frac{A_{req}}{L} = \frac{145}{24} = 6.04 \text{ ft}$$

Use $B = 6.5$ ft to provide some margin for footing weight and rounding.
Check area: $A = 24 \times 6.5 = 156$ ft².

solution_steps.title: Check Including Footing Weight
solution_steps.content:
Assume footing thickness $h = 2.5$ ft.
Footing weight (concrete): $W_f = 24 \times 6.5 \times 2.5 \times 0.150 = 24 \times 6.5 \times 0.375 = 58.5$ kips

Total load including footing:
$$P_{total,with \ footing} = 580 + 58.5 = 638.5 \text{ kips}$$

Actual bearing pressure:
$$q_{actual} = \frac{638.5}{156} = 4.09 \text{ ksf} = 4,090 \text{ psf}$$

This exceeds $q_{all} = 4,000$ psf by about 2.3%, which may be acceptable in practice, but for exact design, increase width slightly.

Revise $B = 6.67$ ft (6 ft 8 in).
New area = $24 \times 6.67 = 160.1$ ft².
Footing weight = $24 \times 6.67 \times 2.5 \times 0.150 = 24 \times 6.67 \times 0.375 = 60.0$ kips.
Total load = $580 + 60 = 640$ kips.
$q = 640 / 160.1 = 4.00$ ksf exactly.

final_answer: The required footing dimensions are $24$ ft long by $6$ ft $8$ in (6.67 ft) wide, with a thickness of $2.5$ ft.
